It was a story about vampire sex was promoted by an advert with the words "Dirtiness is next to antigodliness".}} [[alternative rock]], [[experimental rock]], [[garage rock]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, writer, actor, composer | years_active = 1973–present | label = [[Mute Records|Mute]] | associated_acts = [[Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds]], [[The Birthday Party (band)|The Birthday Party]], [[PJ Harvey]], [[Grinderman]], [[The Birthday Party (band)#The Boys Next Door|The Boys Next Door]] | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Nicholas Edward "Nick" Cave''' (born 22 September 1957) is an Australian musician, songwriter, author, screenwriter, composer and occasional film actor. He is best known for his work as frontman of the critically acclaimed rock band [[Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds]], established in 1983, a group known for its eclectic influences and musical styles. Before that, he fronted the [[post-punk]] group [[The Birthday Party (band)|The Birthday Party]] in the early 1980s, a band renowned for its confrontational live shows and violent sound influenced by [[blues]] and [[free jazz]]. In 2006, he formed the [[garage rock]] band [[Grinderman]], releasing [[Grinderman (album)|its debut album]] the following year. Cave's music is generally characterised by emotional intensity, a wide variety of influences, and lyrical obsessions with religion, death, love and violence.Stephen Thomas Erlewine and Steve Huey, [[Allmusic]], [{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p3854|pure_url=yes}} (((Nick Cave > Biography)))]. Retrieved 30 September 2009. Upon Cave's induction into the [[ARIA Hall of Fame]], ARIA Awards committee chairman Ed St John said, "Nick Cave has enjoyed—and continues to enjoy—one of the most extraordinary careers in the annals of popular music. He is an Australian artist like [[Sidney Nolan]] is an Australian artist—beyond comparison, beyond genre, beyond dispute."[http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,22606485-1702,00.html Nick Cave to enter ARIA Hall of Fame]{{dead link|date=June 2011}} ==Youth, education and family== Cave was born on 22 September 1957 at [[Warracknabeal]], a small country town in the state of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia, to Dawn Cave (née Treadwell) and Colin Frank Cave.{{cite web | url=http://museum.wa.gov.au/whats-on/nick-cave/curators-notes | title=Curator's Notes | publisher=Western Australian Museum | year=2009 | accessdate=16 January 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/22800062 |title=22 December 1949 - LIFE OF MELBOURNE Drama Prize |publisher=Trove.nla.gov.au |date=22 December 1949 |accessdate=5 May 2012}} As a child, he lived in Warracknabeal and then [[Wangaratta]] in rural Victoria. His father, Colin, taught English and maths at the local school; his mother, Dawn, was its librarian.{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2008/feb/23/popandrock.features | title=Old Nick | publisher=The Guardian | date=23 February 2008 | accessdate=30 March 2012 | author=Hattenstone, Simon}} Colin also organised the first [[academic conference|symposium]] on the [[bushranger]] and anti-hero [[Ned Kelly]],Cave, Colin (ed). ''Ned Kelly: Man and Myth''. Wangaratta Adult Education Centre, 1962. ISBN 0-7269-1410-X, p. 10 of whom Nick was enamoured as a child.Lynskey, Dorian (24 February 2006). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2006/feb/24/popandrock "Outback outlaws"], ''The Guardian''. Retrieved 2 March 2013. When Cave was 9 he joined the Cathedral choir of Wangaratta’s Holy Trinity Cathedral. At 13 he was expelled from Wangaratta High School. In 1970, Cave became a boarder and later day boy at [[Caulfield Grammar School]] in Melbourne. Cave was 19 when his father was killed in a car accident; at the moment he was informed of this, his mother Dawn Cave was bailing him out of a [[St Kilda, Victoria|St Kilda]] police station for a charge of burglary. Cave would later recall that his father "died at a point in my life when I was most confused", and "the loss of my father created in my life a vacuum, a space in which my words began to float and collect and find their purpose".Maume, Chris. "[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/nick-cave-devils-advocate-350562.html Nick Cave: Devil's advocate]", ''[[The Independent]]''. Retrieved on 10 November 2008. After his secondary schooling, Cave studied painting (Fine Art) at the Caulfield Institute of Technology (now [[Monash University, Caulfield campus]]) in 1976, but dropped out in 1977 to pursue music. Cave revealed in a 2013 interview:
I really wanted to be a painter—the lifestyle, what I considered a painter to be, I found really attractive when I was young. The solitary aspect of it. But I failed at arts school, so that was that ... I'm glad I'm not a painter now.
He also began using heroin around the time that he left art school.{{cite web | url=http://www.enjoy-your-style.com/nick-cave.html | title=Nick Cave, Style Icon | publisher=enjoy-your-style.com | accessdate=27 September 2012}} On 28 March 2008, he received an honorary Doctor of Laws from this university. In 2010, Cave also received an Honorary Degree from the [[University of Dundee]]{{cite web | url=http://www.dundee.ac.uk/pressreleases/2010/prjune10/nickcave.htm | title=Nick Cave appearance attracts international interest | publisher=University of Dundee | date=10 June 2010 | accessdate=27 September 2012}} and in 2012 he was honored with a Doctor of Letters from Faculty of Arts at the [[University of Brighton]], in recognition of his international standing in the arts and his patronage of Brighton's annual film festival Cine-City.{{cite web | url=http://arts.brighton.ac.uk/whats-on/news/nick-cave-to-receive-honorary-doctorate | title=Nick Cave to receive honorary doctorate | publisher=University of Brighton | date=3 February 2012 | accessdate=27 September 2012}} In 2013, Cave stated that the first live music concert that he attended was at the [[Festival Hall (Melbourne)|Festival Hall]] venue in Melbourne, Australia. The bill consisted of [[Manfred Mann]], [[Deep Purple]] and [[Free (band)|Free]], and Cave recalled that "I remember sitting there and feeling physically the sound going through me."{{cite web|title=10 things Nick Cave said at BIGSOUND 2013|url=http://www.fasterlouder.com.au/news/36893/10-things-Nick-Cave-said-at-BIGSOUND-2013?utm_source=mailbomb&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=11586-Harvest%20Festival%20under%20threat,%20GTM%20dates,%20Nick%20Cave%20at%20BIGSOUND|work=Faster Louder|publisher=Faster Louder Pty Ltd|accessdate=13 September 2013|author=Sarah Smith|date=11 September 2013}} ==Music career== ===Early years and The Birthday Party (1973–83)=== {{Main|The Birthday Party (band)}} In 1973, Cave met [[Mick Harvey]] (guitar), [[Phill Calvert]] (drums), John Cochivera (guitar), Brett Purcell (bass), and Chris Coyne (saxophone); fellow students at Caulfield Grammar. They founded a band with Cave as singer. Their repertoire consisted of proto-punk [[cover versions]] of songs by [[Lou Reed]], [[David Bowie]], [[Alice Cooper]], [[Roxy Music]] and [[Alex Harvey (musician)|Alex Harvey]], among others. Later, the line-up slimmed down to four members including Cave's friend [[Tracy Pew]] on bass. In 1977, after leaving school, they adopted the name The Boys Next Door and began playing predominantly original material. Guitarist and songwriter [[Rowland S. Howard]] joined the band in 1978, expanding to five members. From 1977 until their dissolution in 1983 (by which time they were known as The Birthday Party) the band explored various styles. They were a leader of Melbourne's post-punk scene in the late 1970s, playing hundreds of live shows in Australia before changing their name to The Birthday Party in 1980 and moving to London, then [[West Berlin]]. Cave's Australian girlfriend and muse [[Anita Lane]] accompanied them to London. The band were notorious for their provocative live performances which featured Cave shrieking, bellowing and throwing himself about the stage, backed up by harsh pounding rock music laced with guitar [[Audio feedback|feedback]]. Cave utilised [[old testament]] imagery with lyrics about sin, curses and damnation. The lyrics were full of "[[American gothic]] imagery", talking about horror stories. Cave grew to detest the "[[gothic rock|gothic]]" label; their single "Release the Bats" (1981), described by Harvey as a "comedic interlude", was intended as a sardonic parody of the scene, however it became highly influential in the genre and "a mantra for Goths everywhere".Hanson, Amy. ''Kicking Against the Pricks: An Armchair Guide to Nick Cave''. Helter Skelter Publishing, 2005. ISBN 1-900924-96-X, p. 32 At that time, Cave also became a regular member of a gothic club in London called [[Batcave (club)|The Batcave]].{{cite web |author=Lowey, Nick |url=http://thequietus.com/articles/04921-alien-sex-fiend-interview |title=In The Batcave With Mr & Mrs Fiend: Alien Sex Fiend On Goth & Marriage |work=TheQuietus |date=8 September 2010 |accessdate=2 January 2012}} After establishing a cult following in Europe and Australia, The Birthday Party disbanded in 1984. Howard and Cave found it difficult to continue working together and both were rather worn down from alcohol and drug use. ===Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds (1984–present)=== [[File:Nick Cave 1986.jpg|thumb|240px|Cave performing in 1986]] {{Main|Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds}} The band with Cave as their leader and frontman has released fifteen studio albums. [[Pitchfork Media]] calls the group one of rock's "most enduring, redoubtable" bands, with an accomplished discography.Stuart Berman, [[Pitchfork Media]], [http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/12949-from-her-to-eternity-the-first-born-is-dead-kicking-against-the-pricks-your-funeral-my-trial/ "Album reviews: Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds: From Her to Eternity / The First Born is Dead / Kicking Against the Pricks / Your Funeral ... My Trial], 6 May 2009. Retrieved 30 September 2009. Though their sound tends to change considerably from one album to another, the one constant of the band is an unpolished blending of disparate genres, and song structures which provide a vehicle for Cave's virtuosic, frequently histrionic theatrics. Critics Stephen Thomas Erlewine and Steve Huey wrote: "With the Bad Seeds, Cave continued to explore his obsessions with religion, death, love, America, and violence with a bizarre, sometimes self-consciously eclectic hybrid of blues, gospel, rock, and arty post-punk." Reviewing 2008's ''[[Dig, Lazarus, Dig!!!]]'' album, ''[[NME]]'' used the sentence "[[gothic rock|gothic]] psycho-sexual apocalypse" to describe the "menace" present in the lyrics of the title track.{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/nick-cave-and-the-bad-seeds/9484 |title= Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds Dig!!! Lazarus Dig!!! (album review) |work=NME |date=21 February 2008 |accessdate=2-1-2012}} Their most recent work, ''[[Push the Sky Away]]'', was released in February 2013.{{cite web|last=Roffman|first=Michael|title=New Music: Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds – "We No Who U R"|url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2012/12/new-music-nick-cave-and-the-bad-seeds-we-no-who-u-r/|publisher=Consequence of Sound|accessdate=10 December 2012}} In mid-August 2013, Cave was a 'First Longlist' finalist for the 9th Coopers AMP, alongside artists such as [[Bob Evans (musician)|Kevin Mitchell]] and [[The Drones (Australian band)|The Drones]]. The Australian music prize is worth [[Australian dollar|A$]]30,000 and the 2013 winner will be announced in March 2014.{{cite web|title=Nick Cave, The Drones, Bob Evans Make Longlist For $30,000 Coopers AMP|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/nick-cave-the-drones-bob-evans-make-longlist-for-30000-coopers-amp/|work=Music Feeds|publisher=Music Feeds|accessdate=19 August 2013|author=Mike Hohnen|date=15 August 2013}} In September 2013 interview, Cave explained that he returned to using a typewriter for songwriting after his experience with the ''Nocturama'' album, as he "could walk in on a bad day and hit 'delete' and that was the end of it". Cave believes that he lost valuable work due to a "bad day". ===Solo work=== {{BLP unsourced section|date=September 2013}} In addition to his performances with [[Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds]], Cave has, since the 1990s, performed live 'solo' tours with himself on piano/vocals, [[Warren Ellis (musician)|Warren Ellis]] on violin/accordion and various others on bass and drums. ===Grinderman=== {{Main|Grinderman}} In 2006 Cave formed Grinderman - himself on vocals, guitar, organ & piano, [[Warren Ellis (musician)|Warren Ellis]] (tenor guitar, electric mandolin, violin, viola, guitar, backing vocals), [[Martyn P. Casey]] (bass, guitar, backing vocals) and [[Jim Sclavunos]] (drums, percussion, backing vocals). The alternative rock outfit was formed as "a way to escape the weight of The Bad Seeds."{{cite journal|last1=Cave|first1=Nick|year=2010|title=And Now It's Cave's ''Other'' Deranged Blues Band!|journal=[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut]]|issue=September 2010|page=55|accessdate=21 December 2010}} The band's name was inspired by a [[Memphis Slim]] song, "Grinder Man Blues," which Cave is noted to have started singing during one of the band's early rehearsal sessions. The band's eponymous debut studio album, ''[[Grinderman (album)|Grinderman]]'', was released in 2007 to extremely positive reviews and the band's second and final studio album, ''[[Grinderman 2]]'', was released in 2010 to a similar reception. Grinderman's first public performance was at [[All Tomorrow's Parties (music festival)|All Tomorrow's Parties]] in April 2007 where [[Bobby Gillespie]] from [[Primal Scream]] accompanied Grinderman on backing vocals and percussion. In December 2011, after performing at [[Meredith Music Festival]], Cave announced that Grinderman were over.{{cite web|title=Nick Cave announces that Grinderman are "over" - News | thevine.com.au|url=http://www.thevine.com.au/music/news/nick-cave-announces-that-grinderman-was-%27over%2720111211.aspx|work=The Vine|author=Marcus|date=11 December 2011|accessdate=11 December 2011}}{{dead link|date=March 2012}} ===Music in film=== Cave's work was featured in a scene in the 1986 film, ''Dogs in Space'', by Richard Lowenstein.[http://wwwmcc.murdoch.edu.au/ReadingRoom/film/dbase/1997/pascho.htm ''Dogs in Space''], [[Murdoch University]] [[Reading Room]]. Retrieved on 25 February 2010. Cave performed parts of the Boys Next Door song "[[Shivers (song)|Shivers]]" twice during the film, once on video and once live. Another early fan of Cave's was German director [[Wim Wenders]], who lists Cave, along with [[Lou Reed]] and [[Portishead (band)|Portishead]], as among his favorites.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/05/25/2254785.htm "Wenders unveils ode to rock'n'roll at Cannes"], ''[[ABC News (Australia)]]''. Retrieved on 25 November 2008. Two of Cave's songs were featured in his 1987 film ''[[Wings of Desire]]''.Dave Tacon, "[http://www.sensesofcinema.com/2003/great-directors/wenders/ Wim Wenders]", [[Senses of Cinema]]. Retrieved on 25 November 2008. Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds also make a cameo appearance in this film. Two more songs were included in Wenders' 1993 sequel ''[[Faraway, So Close!]]'', including the title track. The soundtrack for Wenders' 1991 film ''[[Until the End of the World]]'' features Cave's "(I'll Love You) Till the End of the World." His most recent production, ''[[Palermo Shooting]]'', also contains a Nick Cave song, as does his 2003 documentary ''[[The Soul of a Man]]''."[http://www.pbs.org/theblues/aboutfilms/wenders.html The Blues: The Soul of a Man]", [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]. Retrieved on 25 November 2008. Cave's songs have also appeared in a number of Hollywood blockbusters - "There is a Light" appears on the 1995 soundtrack for [[Batman Forever]], and "[[Red Right Hand]]" appeared in a number of films including ''[[The X-Files]]'', ''[[Dumb & Dumber]]''; ''[[Scream (1996 film)|Scream]]'', its sequels ''[[Scream 2]]'' and ''[[Scream 3|3]]'', and ''[[Hellboy]]'' (performed by [[Pete Yorn]]). In ''[[Scream 3]]'', the song was given a reworking with Cave writing new lyrics and adding an orchestra to the arrangement of the track. "People Ain't No Good" was featured in the animated movie ''[[Shrek 2]]'' and the song "O Children" was featured in the 2010 movie of ''[[Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1]].'' In 2000 [[Andrew Dominik]] used "Release the Bats" in his film ''[[Chopper (film)|Chopper]]''. Numerous other movies use Cave's songs including ''[[Box of Moonlight]]'' (1996), ''[[Mr In-Between]]'' (2001), ''[[Romance & Cigarettes]]'' (2005), ''[[Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant]]'' (2009), ''[[The Freshman (1990 film)|The Freshman]]'', ''[[Gas Food Lodging]]'', ''[[Kevin & Perry Go Large]]'', ''[[About Time (2013 film)|About Time]]'' His works also appear in a number of major TV programs among them ''[[Trauma (TV series)|Trauma]]'', ''[[The L Word]]'', ''[[Traveler (TV series)|Traveler]]'', ''[[The Unit]]'', ''[[I Love the '70s (UK TV series)|I Love the '70s]]'', ''Outpatient'', ''[[The Others (TV series)|The Others]]'', ''[[Nip/Tuck]]'', and ''[[Californication (TV series)|Californication]]'', and most recently in the BBC series "Peaky Blinders". ===Collaborations=== Nick Cave has also played with [[Shane MacGowan]], in a [[cover version]] of [[Bob Dylan]]'s "Death is Not the End", and [[Louis Armstrong]]'s "[[What a Wonderful World]]". Cave has also performed "What a Wonderful World" live with [[The Flaming Lips]]. Cave recorded a cover version of the Pogues song "[[Rainy Night in Soho]]", written by MacGowan. [[File:NICK CAVE 2006-11-11 21-58Uhr 019.jpg|thumb|left|Nick Cave at a solo concert in [[Mainz]], Germany on 11 November 2006.]] MacGowan also sings a version of "Lucy", released on ''B-Sides and Rarities''. On 3 May 2008, during the ''Dig, Lazarus, Dig!!!'' tour Shane MacGowan joined [[Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds]] on stage to perform "Lucy" at Dublin Castle in Ireland. [[Pulp (band)|Pulp]]'s single "[[Bad Cover Version]]" includes on its B-side a cover version by Cave of that band's song "[[Disco 2000]]". On the Deluxe Edition of Pulp's ''[[Different Class]]'' another take of this cover can be found. In 2000, one of Cave's heroes, [[Johnny Cash]], covered Cave's "[[The Mercy Seat (song)|The Mercy Seat]]" on the album ''American III: Solitary Man'', seemingly repaying Cave for the compliment he paid by covering Cash's "The Singer" (originally "The Folk Singer") on his ''Kicking Against the Pricks'' album. Cave was then invited to be one of many rock and [[country music|country]] artists to contribute to the liner notes of the retrospective ''[[The Essential Johnny Cash]]'' CD, released to coincide with Cash's 70th birthday. Subsequently, Cave cut a duet with Cash on a version of [[Hank Williams]]' "[[I'm So Lonesome I Could Cry]]" for Cash's ''[[American IV: The Man Comes Around]]'' album (2002). A similar duet, the American folk song "Cindy", was released posthumously on the "Johnny Cash: Unearthed" boxset. Cave's song "Let the Bells Ring" is a posthumous tribute to Cash. Cave has also covered the song "Wanted Man" which is best known as performed by Johnny Cash but is a Bob Dylan composition. In 2004, Cave gave a hand to [[Marianne Faithfull]] on the album, ''Before the Poison''. He co-wrote and produced three songs ("Crazy Love", "There is a Ghost" and "Desperanto"), and the Bad Seeds are featured on all of them. He is also featured on "The Crane Wife" (originally by [[The Decemberists]]), on Faithfull's 2008 album, ''[[Easy Come, Easy Go (Marianne Faithfull album)|Easy Come, Easy Go]]''. Cave collaborated with the band [[Current 93]] on their album ''[[All the Pretty Little Horses]]'', where he sings the title track, a lullaby. For his 1996 album ''[[Murder Ballads]]'', Cave recorded "[[Where the Wild Roses Grow]]" with [[Kylie Minogue]], and "Henry Lee" with [[PJ Harvey]]. Cave also took part in the "X-Files" compilation CD with some other artists, where he reads parts from the Bible combined with own texts, like "Time Jesum ...", he outed himself as a fan of the series some years ago, but since he does not watch much TV, it was one of the only things he watched. He collaborated on the 2003 single "Bring It On", with [[Chris Bailey (musician)|Chris Bailey]], formerly of the Australian punk group, The Saints. Cave contributed vocals to the song "Sweet Rosyanne", on the 2006 album ''Catch That Train!'' from Dan Zanes & Friends, a children's music group. In 2011, Cave recorded a cover of the Zombies' "[[She's Not There]]" with [[Neko Case]], which was used at the end of the first episode of the fourth season of ''[[True Blood]]''. ====Film scores and theatre music==== In 2001, Cave recorded a cover of [[The Beatles]]' "Let It Be" for the film ''[[I Am Sam]]'',{{cite web|title=Various – I Am Sam|url=http://www.discogs.com/Various-I-Am-Sam/release/1072040|work=Discogs|publisher=Discogs|accessdate=6 December 2013|year=2001}} and co-wrote and recorded the song "To Be By Your Side," for the soundtrack of the 2001 French documentary ''[[Le Peuple Migrateur]]'' (called ''Winged Migration'' in the US).{{cite web|title=Bruno Coulais – Winged Migration|url=http://www.discogs.com/Bruno-Coulais-Winged-Migration/release/4922199|work=Discogs|publisher=Discogs|accessdate=6 December 2013|date=30 October 2012}} Cave creates original film scores with fellow Bad Seeds band member [[Warren Ellis (musician)|Warren Ellis]]—they first teamed up in 2005 to work on ''[[The Proposition]]'', for which Cave also wrote the screenplay.[http://www.infilm.com.au/?p=87&_r=true Review: The Proposition (2005)]. In Film Australia (12 October 2005). Retrieved on 15 October 2012. In 2006, Cave and Ellis composed the music for [[Andrew Dominik]]'s adaptation of [[Ron Hansen (novelist)|Ron Hansen]]'s ''[[The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford]]''.[http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/11121-the-assassination-of-jesse-james-by-the-coward-robert-ford/ Nick Cave and Warren Ellis The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford]. Pitchfork.com (1 February 2008). Retrieved on 15 October 2012. By the time Dominik's film was released, Hillcoat was preparing his next project, [[The Road (2009 film)|The Road]], [[Cormac McCarthy]]'s story of a father and son struggling through the ruined landscape of global catastrophe. Cave and Ellis wrote and recorded the score for the film which was released in 2009.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/r25c Nick Cave and Warren Ellis The Road Review]. BBC.co.uk (22 December 2009). Retrieved on 15 October 2012. In early 2011, Cave and Ellis composed the music for the Mexican film ''Dias de Gracias''.[http://www.nickcaveandwarrenellis.com/works/dias-de-gracias-days-of-grace-2012 Dias de Gracias (Days of Grace)(2012)]. Nickcaveandwarenellis.com . Retrieved on 15 October 2012. Later in 2011, they reunited with Hillcoat to score his latest picture ''[[Lawless (film)|Lawless]]''. Set in Depression-era [[Franklin County, Virginia]], US, the film was released in August 2012 (US) and September 2012 (UK).[http://www.guardian.co.uk/film/2012/aug/26/lawless-nick-cave-interview Nick Cave: 'Lawless is not so much a true story as a true myth']. Guardian.co.uk (26 August 2012). Retrieved on 15 October 2012. Cave and Ellis also possess documentary-score composition experience. In 2007, the pair composed the score for Geoffrey Smith's harrowing film, ''[[The English Surgeon]]'', which traces Dr. [[Henry Marsh (neurosurgeon)|Henry Marsh]]'s struggle to bring modern neurosurgery to the confusion of post-Soviet Ukraine, and in 2009 ''The Girls of Phnom Penh'', Matthew Watson's picture exploring Cambodia's "virginity trade", was also accompanied by a Cave-Ellis score.[http://pitchfork.com/news/35706-nick-cave-and-warren-ellis-score-sex-trade-documentary-film/ Nick Cave and Warren Ellis Score Sex Trade Documentary Film]. Pitchfork.com (23 June 2009). Retrieved on 15 October 2012. Cave's novel ''[[The Death of Bunny Munro]]'', published in 2009, was released as an audiobook and Cave worked with Ellis, Iain Forsyth and Jane Pollard on the soundtrack. Forsyth and Pollard referred to the soundtrack as a 3D experience and stated: "We've not heard anything like this before – the result sits somewhere between a film soundtrack, a radio play and an hallucination."{{cite web|title=Nick Cave releases soundtrack for novel 'The Death Of Bunny Munro'|url=http://www.nme.com/news/nick-cave/47165|work=NME|publisher=IPC Media Entertainment Network|accessdate=6 December 2013|date=7 September 2009}} Cave and Ellis created music for the [[Vesturport]] productions ''[[Woyzeck]]'', ''[[The Metamorphosis]]'' and ''[[Faust]]''.{{cite web|title=Faust inspired by Goeth|url=http://vesturport.com/theater/faust/|work=Vesturport|publisher=Vesturport|accessdate=6 December 2013}} ==Writing== Cave released his first book, ''King Ink'', in 1988. It is a collection of lyrics and plays, including collaborations with [[Lydia Lunch]]. In 1997, he followed up with ''King Ink II'', containing lyrics, poems, and the transcript of a radio essay he did for the [[BBC]] in July 1996, "The Flesh Made Word," discussing in biographical format his relationship with Christianity. [[File:Nick Cave in New York City 2009 portrait 2.jpg|thumb|Cave reading from ''[[The Death of Bunny Munro]]'' in New York City, 2009.]] While he was based in [[West Berlin]], Cave started working on what was to become his debut novel, ''[[And the Ass Saw the Angel]]'' (1989). Significant crossover is evident between the [[Theme (literature)|theme]]s in the book and the lyrics Cave wrote in the late stages of the Birthday Party and the early stage of his solo career. "Swampland", from ''Mutiny'', in particular, uses the same linguistic stylings ('mah' for 'my', for instance) and some of the same themes (the narrator being haunted by the memory of a girl called Lucy, being hunted like an animal, approaching death and execution). On 21 January 2008, a special edition of Cave's novel ''And the Ass Saw the Angel'' was released.{{cite web|url=http://www.side-line.com/news_comments.php?id=28460_0_2_1_C |title=Nick Cave sees debut novel 'And The Ass Saw the Angel' re-released as collectors edition |publisher=Side-line.com |date=15 January 2008 |accessdate=2 June 2011}} Cave's second novel ''[[The Death of Bunny Munro]]'' was published on 8 September 2009 by Harper Collins books.[http://www.nme.com/news/nme/46636 Nick Cave announces release date for new novel | News]. Nme.Com (11 August 2009). Retrieved on 29 September 2010.[http://www.harpercollins.ca/books/9781554685400/The_Death_of_Bunny_Munro/index.aspx "The Death of Bunny Munro: A Novel By Nick Cave"] September 2009. It tells the story of a sex-addicted salesman, was also released as a [[binaural recording|binaural]] audio-book produced by British Artists [[Iain Forsyth and Jane Pollard]] and an iPhone app.Breihan, Tom [http://pitchfork.com/news/36434-nick-caves-new-novel-ibunny-munroi-gets-its-own-iphone-app-tour/ "Nick Cave's New Novel Bunny Munro Gets its Own iPhone App, Tour"] September 2009. The book originally started as a screenplay Cave was going to write for [[John Hillcoat]].Khanna, Vish [http://exclaim.ca/articles/multiarticlesub.aspx?csid1=137&csid2=946&fid1=41546 "Conversations: Nick Cave"] at ''[[Exclaim!]]'' October 2009. As proof of his interest in scripture, so evident in his lyrics and his prose writing, Cave wrote the foreword to a [[Canongate Books|Canongate]] publication of the ''[[Gospel according to Mark]]'', published in the UK in 1998. The American edition of the same book (published by [[Grove Press]]) contains a foreword by the noted American writer [[Barry Hannah]]. Cave is a contributor to the 2009 rock biography on [[The Triffids]] ''Vagabond Holes: David McComb and the Triffids'', edited by Australian academics [[Niall Lucy]] and Chris Coughran.Niall Lucy and Chris Coughran, eds. Vagabond Holes: David McComb and The Triffids (Fremantle: Fremantle Press, 2009). ==Acting== Cave's first film appearance was in [[Wim Wenders]]' 1987 film ''[[Wings of Desire]]'', in which he and the Bad Seeds are shown performing at a concert in Berlin. Cave has made occasional appearances as an actor. He appears alongside [[Blixa Bargeld]] in the 1988 [[Peter Sempel]] film "Dandy", playing dice, singing and speaking from his Berlin apartment. He is most prominently featured in the 1989 film ''[[Ghosts... of the Civil Dead]]'', written and directed by [[John Hillcoat]], and in the 1991 film ''[[Johnny Suede]]'' with [[Brad Pitt]]. Cave appeared in the 2005 homage to [[Leonard Cohen]], ''[[Leonard Cohen: I'm Your Man]]'', in which he performed "I'm Your Man" solo, and "Suzanne" with [[Julie Christensen]] and [[Perla Batalla]]. He also appeared in the 2007 film adaptation of Ron Hansen's novel ''[[The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford]]'', where he sings a song about Jesse James. Cave and Warren Ellis are credited for the film's soundtrack. His interest in the work of [[Edward Gorey]] led to his participation in the [[BBC Radio 3]] programme ''Guest + Host = Ghost'', featuring [[Peter Blegvad]] and the radiophonic sound of the [[Langham Research Centre]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio3/betweentheears/pip/aao11/ |title=(none) - Between The Ears - Guest + Host = Ghost |publisher=BBC |date=31 December 2005 |accessdate=14 February 2013}} Cave has also lent his voice in narrating the award-winning animated film ''[[The Cat Piano]]''. It was directed by [[Eddie White (director)|Eddie White]] and Ari Gibson (of [[The People's Republic Of Animation]]), produced by Jessica Brentnall and has music by [[Benjamin Speed]].{{cite web|url=http://catpianofilm.com/ |title=The Cat Piano |publisher=Catpianofilm.com |accessdate=2 June 2011}} ==Screenwriting== Cave wrote the screenplay for ''[[The Proposition]]'', a film set in the colonial Australian [[Outback]]. Directed by John Hillcoat and filmed in Queensland in 2004, it premiered in October 2005 and was later released worldwide to critical acclaim.Brett McCracken, [http://www.relevantmagazine.com/pc_article.php?id=7190 Film Review of ''The Proposition''], ''[[Relevant Magazine]]''. Retrieved 25 November 2008. Cave explained his personal background in relation to writing the film's screenplay in a 2013 interview:
I had written long-form before but it is pure story-telling in script writing and that goes back as far as I can remember for me, not just with my father but with myself. I slept in the same bedroom as my sister for many years, until it became indecent to do so and I would tell her stories every night—that is how she would get to sleep. She would say "tell me a story" so I would tell her a story. So that ability, I very much had that from the start and I used to enjoy that at school so actually to write a script—it suddenly felt like I was just making up a big story.
The movie reviewer for British newspaper ''[[The Independent]]'' called ''The Proposition'' "peerless," "a star-studded and uncompromisingly violent outlaw film."Will Self, "[http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/the-proposition-bringing-the-revisionist-western-to-the-australian-outback-468212.html The Proposition: Bringing the revisionist Western to the Australian outback]," The Independent. Retrieved 25 November 2008. It even features on a website promoting tourism to the area."[http://www.outback-australia-travel-secrets.com/australian_outback_movies.html Australian Outback Movies]," on Outback Australia Travel Guide. Retrieved 25 November 2008. The generally [[ambient music|ambient]] soundtrack was recorded by Cave and Warren Ellis. In 2006 it was revealed that, at the request of friend [[Russell Crowe]], Cave wrote a script for a proposed sequel to ''[[Gladiator (2000 film)|Gladiator]]'' which was rejected by the studio.Dawtrey, Adam, "[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117945764.html?categoryid=2185&cs=1 10 Screenwriters to Watch: Nick Cave]," ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', 22 June 2006. An announcement in February 2010 stated that [[Andy Serkis]] and Cave would collaborate on a motion-capture movie of the Brecht and Weill musical play ''The Threepenny Opera''. As of September 2012, the project has not been released.{{cite web|title=Serkis, Cave plan motion-capture Opera|url=http://www.screendaily.com/festivals/berlin/european-film-market/serkis-cave-plan-motion-capture-opera/5010840.article|work=Screen Daily|publisher=Media Business Insight Limited|accessdate=24 September 2013|author=Mike Goodridge|date=15 February 2010}} Cave wrote a screenplay titled ''The Wettest County in the World'',{{cite web|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/archives/of_course_he_did_nick_cave_confirms_hell_score_john_hillcoats_the_wettest_c/ |title= Nick Cave Confirms He'll Score John Hillcoat's 'The Wettest County' |first=Simon |last=Dang |date=4 February 2011 |work=[[indieWIRE]] |accessdate=9 February 2011}} which was used for the 2012 film ''[[Lawless (2012 film)|Lawless]]'', directed again by John Hillcoat, and starring [[Tom Hardy]] and [[Shia LaBeouf]]. The film opened in theaters on 29 August 2012.Pelly, Jenn, "[http://pitchfork.com/news/47281-nick-cave-warren-ellis-lawless-music-features-mark-lanegan-emmylou-harris-ralph-stanley-more/]," ''[[Pitchfork Media|Pitchfork.com]]'', 27 July 2012. ==Personal life== [[File:Howard Arkley Nick Cave.jpg|thumb|Banner in Melbourne of [[Howard Arkley]]'s 1999 portrait of Nick Cave, held at the [[National Portrait Gallery (Australia)|National Portrait Gallery]]]] Cave dated [[Anita Lane]] from the late 1970s to mid-1980s. Cave and Lane recorded together on a few occasions. Their most notable collaborations include Lane's 'cameo' verse on Cave's Bob Dylan cover "Death Is Not The End" from the album ''[[Murder Ballads]]'', and a cover of the [[Serge Gainsbourg]]/[[Jane Birkin]] song "''Je t'aime, moi non plus/ I love you, nor do I''". Lane co-wrote the lyrics to the title track for Cave's 1984 LP, ''[[From Her to Eternity]]'', as well as the lyrics of the song "Stranger Than Kindness" from ''[[Your Funeral, My Trial]]''. Cave, [[Lydia Lunch]] and Lane wrote a comic book together, entitled ''AS-FIX-E-8'', in the style of the old "Pussy Galore"/Russ Meyer movies. Cave is father to four sons.{{cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/interview-nick-cave-1-1355795 |title=Interview: Nick Cave |publisher=The Scotsman |date=28 August 2009 |accessdate=11 October 2013}}{{cite web|author=David Bianculli |url=http://www.wbur.org/npr/137220550/nick-cave-an-australian-on-love-and-death-in-america |title=Nick Cave: An Australian On Love And Death In America | WBUR & NPR |publisher=Wbur.org |date=17 June 2011 |accessdate=11 October 2013}} Cave left West Berlin and moved to [[São Paulo (city)|São Paulo]], Brazil, where he met Brazilian journalist Viviane Carneiro. They had a son, Luke (born in 1991). Cave lived in [[Vila Madalena]] for three years.{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com.br/sao-paulo/en/music/features/215/back-to-black-goths-return-to-sao-paulo |title=Back to black: dark music's return - Features - Music - Time Out São Paulo |publisher=Timeout.com.br |date= |accessdate=11 October 2013}} He was married for 6 years and divorced in 1996.{{cite web|url=http://www.nick-cave.com/interviews/index.php?subaction=showfull&id=1051742708&archive=&cnshow=headlines&start_from= |title=Nick Cave Interviews |publisher=Nick-cave.com |date= |accessdate=11 October 2013}} Cave's son Jethro (born in 1991) grew up with his mother, Beau Lazenby, in Melbourne, Australia and has a career in modelling; they did not meet until he was about seven or eight.{{cite web|url=http://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/models-and-rockers-jethro-cave-and-leah-weller-6729475.html |title=Models and rockers: Jethro Cave and Leah Weller - Life & Style - London Evening Standard |publisher=Standard.co.uk |date=12 November 2009 |accessdate=14 February 2013}}{{Cite news|author=Fiona Byrne|work=Herald & Weekly Times|title=Cave boy joins cool kids club |url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,,24412744-27258,00.html |accessdate=1 January 2009|date=28 September 2008}} Cave briefly dated [[PJ Harvey]] during the mid-1990s before he met British model Susie Bick in 1997. Bick was the cover model on the [[The Damned (band)|Damned]]'s 1985 album ''[[Phantasmagoria (The Damned album)|Phantasmagoria]]'' and a [[Vivienne Westwood]] model—she gave up her job when they married in 1999. They have twin sons, Arthur and Earl (born in 2000).{{Cite news| url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/features/story/0,11710,885692,00.html | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Feelings are a Bourgeois luxury | first=Lindsay | last=Baker | date=1 February 2003 | accessdate=20 May 2010}}{{cite web|author=Pero Bilcic |url=http://www.nick-cave.com/_interviews.php?subaction=showfull&id=1051743552&archive=&cnshow=headlines&start_from= |title=Nick Cave Online |publisher=Nick-cave.com |accessdate=2 June 2011}} Bick is also the model on the cover of the album ''[[Push the Sky Away]]''.{{cite web|author=Craig McLean |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/on-stage-im-just-me-having-a-bad-day-nick-cave-on-40-years-of-music-and-mayhem-8607908.html |title='On stage I'm just me having a bad day': Nick Cave on 40 years of music and mayhem - Profiles - People |publisher=The Independent |date=12 May 2013 |accessdate=11 October 2013}} Cave left Australia in 1980 and lives with his family in [[Brighton and Hove|Brighton]], England, UK.{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/music/cave-dreading-aria-induction/2007/10/22/1192940965729.html |title=Cave 'dreading' ARIA induction - Music - Entertainment |publisher=smh.com.au |date=22 October 2007 |accessdate=11 October 2013}} Cave performed "Into My Arms" at the televised funeral of [[Michael Hutchence]], but insisted that the cameras cease rolling during his performance. Cave is the godfather of Hutchence's daughter Heavenly Hiraani Tiger Lily.{{cite web|title=Nick Cave: Fan Factoids|url=http://everguide.com.au/music/gigs-and-festivals/news/nick-cave-fan-factoids-.aspx|work=Everguide|publisher=Lifelounge Pty Ltd|accessdate=19 October 2013|author=Lauren Bertacchini|date=26 February 2013}} In the past, Cave identified as a Christian. In his recorded lectures on music and songwriting, he has claimed that any true love song is a song for God and has ascribed the mellowing of his music to a shift in focus from the Old to the New Testaments. He does not belong to a particular denomination and has distanced himself from "religion as being an American thing, in which the name of God has been hijacked".{{cite web|last=Bartlett |first=Thomas |url=http://dir.salon.com/story/ent/feature/2004/11/18/cave/index.html |title=The Resurrection of Nick Cave: The most talented romantic Christian poet rocker in the world talks to Salon about his new record and his return to songwriting form. Interview in Salon Magazine, 18 November 2004 |publisher=Dir.salon.com |date=18 November 2004 |accessdate=2 June 2011}} He said in a ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' article: "I'm not religious, and I'm not a Christian, but I do reserve the right to believe in the possibility of a god. It's kind of defending the indefensible, though; I'm critical of what religions are becoming, the more destructive they're becoming. But I think as an artist, particularly, it's a necessary part of what I do, that there is some divine element going on within my songs."{{Cite news|author=John Payne |work=Los Angeles Times |title=Nick Cave's master plan |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/music/la-et-nick-cave-20101129,0,4557691.story |accessdate=29 November 2010 |date=29 November 2010}} When asked in 2009 about whether he believed in a personal God, Cave's reply was: "No".{{cite web| quote=Do I personally believe in a personal God? No.| url= http://www.guardian.co.uk/books/audio/2009/sep/10/nick-cave-bunny-munro | publisher=The Guardian | title= Nick Cave on The Death of Bunny Munro|date=11 September 2009|accessdate=14 December 2013}} When interviewed by Jarvis Cocker on 12 September 2010, for his BBC Radio 6 show "Jarvis Cocker's Sunday Service", Cave stated: "I believe in God in spite of religion, not because of it."{{cite web|title=Jarvis Cocker's Sunday Service|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00tqjr4|work=BBC 6|publisher=BBC|accessdate=13 December 2013|author=Jarvis Cocker|date=12 September 2010}} In 2009, Cave joked about plans to erect a gold statue of himself in his hometown of Warracknabeal, based on a foot-high scale model, which, according to Cave, features him "naked on a rearing horse. I have a modest loincloth on. It's this rather wonderful homoerotic work of art".[http://www.nme.com/news/nick-cave/47596 "Nick Cave delays plans to erect gold statue of himself"] (1 October 2009), ''NME''. Retrieved 2 March 2013. [[Shire of Yarriambiack|Yarriambiack Council]] acknowledged the humour and tourist appeal behind Cave's proposal, daring him to "build a 50m-high Nick Cave with a viewing platform."Brown, Terry (24 June 2008). [http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/nick-cave-on-high-horse/story-e6frf7kx-1111116715854 "Nick Cave on high horse"], ''Herald Sun''. Retrieved 2 March 2013. In a mid-September 2013 conference keynote Q&A session, Cave explained: "I am Nick Cave and there is no going back to what I was. And on some level, I see that as being successful in my job and on the other hand sometimes it's fucking exhausting." A film about the life of Nick Cave entitled ''20,000 Days on Earth'' and directed by artists [[Iain Forsyth and Jane Pollard]] is due for cinematic release in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/jun/27/day-in-the-life-nick-cave?INTCMP=SRCH |title=Interview: A Day in the Life of Nick Cave |publisher=The Guardian |date=27 July 2013 |accessdate=22 October 2013}} ==Discography== [[File:Nick Cave 3.jpg|alt=|thumb|Cave performing in 2008]] {{Main|Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds discography|l1=Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds|The Birthday Party (band)#Discography|l2=The Birthday Party discography|Grinderman discography|13=Grinderman discography}} ===Studio albums=== ====[[The Birthday Party (band)|The Boys Next Door]]==== *1979 : ''[[Door, Door]]'' ====[[The Birthday Party (band)|The Birthday Party]]==== *1980 : ''[[The Birthday Party (The Birthday Party album)|The Birthday Party]] *1981 : ''[[Prayers on Fire]]'' *1982 : ''[[Junkyard (album)|Junkyard]]'' ====[[Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds]]==== *1984 : ''[[From Her to Eternity]]'' *1985 : ''[[The Firstborn Is Dead]]'' *1986 : ''[[Kicking Against the Pricks]]'' *1986 : ''[[Your Funeral...
